{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-050-14-A |Item_parent=Genito-scrotal pathology in boys and men |Item_parent_short=Genito-scrotal pathology in boys and men |Rank=A |Title=Know the principles of the management of preputial infections, phimosis and paraphimosis. |Description=None |Rubric=Management |Contributors=Cédric Lebâcle, Alice Faure |Order=14}}
*In children, physiological phimosis cannot be treated before the age of 3-4 years. *Balanoposthitis requires a prescription for local antiseptic-based care in a penis bath. *The release of preputial adhesions can be helped by the application of dermocorticoids for several weeks. *From the age of 5-6 years, if local treatments fail, or in adults, surgical treatment (foreskin plasty or post-hectomy) may be considered. *The onset of paraphimosis requires emergency manual reduction. The operator must perform a recalibration manoeuvre by tilting the preputial ring forwards with the index and middle fingers while exerting pressure on the glans with the thumbs. If this fails, an emergency posthectomy should be considered.

question.title: What is the recommended approach for managing preputial infections in children?

option_a.title: Local antiseptic-based care and observation
option_a.description: Treatment involves applying local antiseptic-based care and waiting for the condition to resolve on its own

option_b.title: Emergency manual reduction and antibiotics
option_b.description: The condition requires immediate emergency manual reduction and prescription of antibiotics

option_c.title: Dermocorticoids and observation
option_c.description: Application of dermocorticoids and waiting for the condition to resolve on its own

option_d.title: Surgical treatment after 5-6 years of age
option_d.description: Treatment involves surgical intervention after the child is 5-6 years old
